channel.title: My Webclient php file

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Just a brief question, you do understand that you can include HTML on a PHP page, right? If you must have the HTML code mixed with the PHP code, for whatever reason, here is a better option.

[code]<?php
$webclient = ’

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. '; ?> Title <?php if(isset($logged)) { echo $webclient; } else { echo "You cannot see the webclient! Please Login."; } ?> [/code]

However, the best option, by far, would be to just keep the PHP and HTML separated…

[code]<?php
// All of your PHP crap.
?>

[/code]

No point in using PHP for outputting HTML information, only use PHP when needed, also, escaping characters in the HTML code like that is redundant. Also, you can take any page with .HTML extension, and make it .PHP and it’ll give the same output. Ex:

index.html changes to index.php --> Nothing changes except file name, and the file can now support PHP code.

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:540237”]Also, with php you can do something like

[code]
$html = "

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. "[/code]

And then echo the the $html variable.[/quote]
I can’t really understand why you’d want to do this, like ever. It’s a waste of resources, makes your code strange and bypasses the output buffering. If you wanted to modify a HTML structure before writing it you’d be better off using a DOM object.

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Funny how “php file”, but really you could make this an HTML file and include it when you need it in your PHP script.

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:540237”]Also, with php you can do something like

[code]
$html = "

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. "[/code]

And then echo the the $html variable.[/quote]You would do,

[code=php]$html = ’

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. ';[/code]

A little PHP hax,

[code=php]<? if (expr) { ?>

<? } else { ?> <? } ?>[/code]

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:10, topic:540237”]you have unescaped strings ^

I believe the only use php has for webclients would parsing parameters to the client for something like a webclient for many servers.

however this can be achieved in other ways as well.[/quote]
Yeah I did a copy paste haha.
But that’s what I was saying, you honestly don’t need to do this outside of html.

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @Learning_Code Learning Code
item.description:
@Learning_Code wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:6, topic:540237”]The code I provided was just an example to show you can have php alongside html instead of loading the applet through php.
Also, a good way to load jars:

[code]

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. [/code] Instead of the applet tag, which has been deprecated (I believe).[/quote]

A lot cleaner and organized.

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

The code I provided was just an example to show you can have php alongside html instead of loading the applet through php.
Also, a good way to load jars:

[code]

Applet failed to run. No Java plug-in was found. [/code] Instead of the applet tag, which has been deprecated (I believe).

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @Learning_Code Learning Code
item.description:
@Learning_Code wrote:

[code]<?php require 'core/init.php'; $general->logged_in_protect();

?>
<!doctype html>

Login
<?php include 'includes/menu.php'; ?>

Your username and password for this portion of the website is the same as you'd enter to log into the game.

[/code]

Where in this code does it load the loader.class or client.class? I’m so confused looking at that. I’m extremely new to Php. Just something I through together from what I thought was right.

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Learning Code, post:3, topic:540237”]I’m a perfectionist, if I build my site with many php files, I want every file possible in php. As well as a learning experience.

OT: Is there a better way of coding this?[/quote]
I hope you know that in a php file, you can do this:

[code]<?php
require ‘core/init.php’;
$general->logged_in_protect();

?>
<!doctype html>

Login
<?php include 'includes/menu.php'; ?>

Your username and password for this portion of the website is the same as you'd enter to log into the game.

[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: My Webclient php file
item.dc:creator: @Learning_Code Learning Code
item.description:
@Learning_Code wrote:

I Haven’t tested this yet as I cant be bothered at 5am to make a webhost and upload everything, but for HTML I know this code works for playing a webclient, would this work for php? If you can make the code cleaner feel free to do so or just give me some tips.

echo "<applet name=\"Title here\" width=\"780\" height=\"540\" archive=\"client.jar\" code=\"Loader.class\">\n"; echo "<param name=\"java_arguments\" value=\"-Xmx1024m\">\n"; echo "</applet>\n"; echo " \n"; echo "</BODY>\n"; echo "</HTML>\n"; echo "</center>\n"; ?>

I’m new to php, and trying to self teach from some website I got the basics from.

Read full topic
